title: 111_hr626
content: The Act titled "Federal Employees Paid Parental Leave Act of 2009" provides for paid parental leave under Title 5. The Act "Federal Employees Paid Parental Leave Act of 2009" allows employees to substitute unpaid leave with paid leave for parental purposes. Paid leave includes 4 weeks of parental leave and any accrued annual or sick leave. Paid parental leave under the Federal Employees Paid Parental Leave Act of 2009 allows employees to use paid leave without using other types of leave first. The paid parental leave is payable from agency funds, not considered annual or vacation leave, and does not carry over if unused after 12 months. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management oversees this provision. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management can create regulations to increase paid parental leave for employees up to 8 administrative workweeks. This decision is based on factors like benefits to the government, costs, private sector trends, and the government's role as an employer. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management can create regulations to increase paid parental leave for employees up to 8 administrative workweeks, considering factors like benefits to the government, costs, private sector trends, impact on lower-income employees, and other necessary factors. The amendment will not be effective for any birth or placement before 6 months from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. PAID PARENTAL LEAVE FOR CONGRESSIONAL EMPLOYEES. Amendment to the Congressional Accountability Act allows covered employees to substitute paid leave for unpaid leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act for parental leave. The Congressional Accountability Act amendment allows covered employees to use paid leave for parental leave, including paid parental leave corresponding to federal employees' entitlement and any additional vacation or sick leave provided by the employer. No requirement to use all available leave before using paid parental leave. The amendment allows paid parental leave to be used by covered employees from available funds within the employing office. Unused leave does not accumulate for future use after the 12-month period. The amendment allows paid parental leave to be used by covered employees within the employing office, effective for births or placements before the end of a 6-month period from the enactment of this Act. Unused leave does not accumulate after 12 months. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENT TO FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE ACT FOR GAO AND LIBRARY OF CONGRESS EMPLOYEES. Amendment to Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 allows GAO and Library of Congress employees to substitute paid leave for FMLA leave. Paid leave available for this purpose is determined by the employer. The amendment allows employees to use paid parental leave corresponding to federal employees' leave weeks, plus any additional vacation or sick leave provided by the employer, without needing to use all vacation or sick leave first. The amendment allows paid parental leave for federal employees to be used within a 12-month period and not accumulate for future use. The amendment allows paid parental leave for federal employees to be used within a 12-month period and not accumulate for future use. It will be effective for any birth or placement occurring before the end of the 6-month period after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION FOR MEMBERS OF THE NATIONAL GUARD AND RESERVES. For National Guard and Reserves members in the Executive Branch, active duty service counts towards leave eligibility. Similarly, Congressional employees in the same situation can also qualify for leave under specific conditions. For National Guard and Reserves members in the Executive Branch, active duty service counts towards leave eligibility. Similarly, employees of the Government Accountability Office or Library of Congress who are National Guard or Reserves members can also qualify for leave under specific conditions. Active duty service by National Guard and Reserves members in the Executive Branch, Government Accountability Office, or Library of Congress counts towards leave eligibility. Active duty service by National Guard and Reserves members in certain government agencies counts towards leave eligibility. The House of Representatives passed the Act on June 4, 2009.
